choices.text: Diarrhea-associated hemolytic uremic syndrome

questions.text: All of the following are associated with low complement levels except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diarrhea associated hemolytic uremic syn­drome

 

Option C:

 

Diarrhea-associated Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS): Typically, in diarrhea-associated HUS, which is often caused by infection with Shiga toxin-producing E. coli, complement levels are not affected. This condition does not usually involve immune complex deposition or complement activation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Lupus Nephritis: In lupus nephritis, an autoimmune condition where the body's own immune system attacks the kidneys, low complement levels are common due to the consumption of complement in the formation of immune complexes.

 

Option B: Mesangiocapillary Glomerulonephritis: This condition, also known as membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, involves the deposition of immune complexes in the mesangium and capillary walls of the kidneys, often leading to persistent low complement levels, particularly C3, due to the activation of the complement system.

 

Option D: Post-infectious Glomerulonephritis: This usually occurs after infections such as streptococcal infection. While it can result in transient low complement levels due to immune complex deposition and complement activation, the levels usually return to normal within several weeks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Low complement levels are typically associated with conditions involving immune complex deposition and activation of the complement pathway, such as lupus nephritis, mesangiocapillary glomerulonephritis, and post-infectious glomerulonephritis. Diarrhea-associated hemolytic uremic syndrome, however, does not commonly involve complement system alterations, setting it apart from other causes of nephritic syndrome with low complement levels.

 

Nephritic syndrome associated with low C3

 

 

(Ref:  10th/ 938)

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman complains of increased fatigue since last 2 years. Her serum creatinine and blood urea nitrogen are raised. USG shows both kidneys symmetrically reduced in size. Kidney biopsy done shows the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Systemic hypertension

 

This is hyaline arteriosclerosis of vessel wall seen in benign hypertension wherein the kidneys are symmetrically contracted.

 

Similar changes can also be seen in diabetes mellitus.

 

Option B:

 

In systemic hypertension, especially long-standing and poorly controlled cases, hyaline arteriosclerosis of the vessel wall can occur, leading to symmetrically reduced kidney size. This finding is consistent with the patient’s presentation and biopsy results.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Polyarteritis nodosa typically presents with vasculitis and fibrinoid necrosis on kidney biopsy. It is characterized by segmental necrotizing inflammation of medium-sized arteries, which would be evident on histological examination.

 

Option C: Malignant hypertension typically presents with "flea-bitten" kidneys on imaging and demonstrates fibrinoid necrosis on kidney biopsy. This patient's presentation, including symmetrically reduced kidney size and the absence of fibrinoid necrosis, is not consistent with malignant hypertension.

 

Option D: Wegener's granulomatosis is characterized by granulomatous inflammation of the vessel wall. However, the histological findings described in the patient's kidney biopsy do not align with this diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Symmetrically reduced kidney size with hyaline arteriosclerosis of the vessel wall is indicative of systemic hypertension.

 

Onion-skinning of blood vessels in kidney is seen in:

 

  • Malignant hypertension
  • Chronic transplant rejection
  • Thrombotic microangiopathies (e.g., HUS, TTP)

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ p492)

questions.text: All of the following are associated with low C3 level except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Goodpasture’s disease

Option C:

Goodpasture’s disease: This is an autoimmune disease where antibodies target the basement membrane in the lungs and kidneys. Typically, it is not associated with low serum C3 levels because the pathophysiology does not involve the classical complement pathway activation that consumes C3.

Goodpasture's disease is not typically associated with low C3 levels. It is an autoimmune disease characterized by the presence of antibodies directed against the glomerular basement membrane and alveolar basement membrane in the lungs. This condition primarily involves the lungs and kidneys. While it can cause glomerulonephritis, it does not usually result in low C3 levels.

Explanation:

Option A: Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis: This condition often follows a streptococcal infection and is characterized by an acute immune response. It leads to decreased levels of complement C3 due to the activation of the complement system by immune complexes deposited in the glomeruli.

Option B: Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis: This chronic condition involves immune complexes and complement deposition in the kidneys, resulting in persistent low serum C3 levels.

Option D: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE): SLE is a systemic autoimmune disease that can cause a wide array of clinical manifestations, including lupus nephritis. Immune complexes formed in SLE activate the complement system, leading to reduced serum C3 levels.

Educational Objective:

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis commonly cause low serum C3 levels due to complement activation and consumption. In contrast, Goodpasture’s disease does not typically result in low C3 levels as its pathogenesis does not involve immune complexes that activate complement. Systemic lupus erythematosus often presents with low C3 due to immune complex-mediated complement activation.

questions.text: In a specimen of kidney, fibrinoid necrosis is seen and onion peel appearance is also present. Most probable pathology is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hyperplastic arteriosclerosis

 

Option B:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Hyaline degeneration refers to the accumulation of homogenous, eosinophilic material (hyaline) in tissues. It is not typically associated with fibrinoid necrosis or an onion peel appearance.

 

Option C: Glomerulosclerosis involves scarring and hardening of the glomeruli in the kidneys. It may not typically present with fibrinoid necrosis and an onion peel appearance.

 

Option D: Fibrillary glomerulonephritis is a renal disease characterized by the deposition of fibrillary immune complexes in the glomeruli. Fibrinoid necrosis and an onion peel appearance are not typically associated with fibrillary glomerulonephritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hyperplastic arteriosclerosis is characterized by "onion skin" or "string of beads" appearance.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 935)

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of autoimmune disorders presents with fatigue, edema, and cola-colored urine. Laboratory studies reveal elevated serum creatinine, proteinuria, and hematuria. Urinalysis shows dysmorphic red blood cells and red cell casts. Renal biopsy reveals cellular crescents and fibrinoid necrosis in glomeruli. Which of these does not cause crescentic glomerulone­phritis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alport syndrome

 

Option B:

 

Alport syndrome is a genetic disorder caused by mutations in genes encoding type IV collagen. It primarily affects the kidneys, ears, and eyes. However, crescentic glomerulonephritis is not a characteristic feature of Alport syndrome.

 

Crescentic glomerulonephritis is a histopathological pattern of glomerular injury characterized by the presence of crescents in Bowman's space. Various diseases and conditions can cause crescentic glomerulonephritis. Let's look at the provided options:

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) is a term used to describe a clinical presentation rather than a specific disease. Conditions like ANCA-associated vasculitis, anti-GBM (Goodpasture's syndrome), and immune complex-mediated glomerulonephritis can present as RPGN with crescents.

 

Option C: Goodpasture's syndrome is an autoimmune disease characterized by the presence of anti-GBM antibodies. It can lead to rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis with crescent formation.

 

Option D: Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) is a systemic vasculitis that affects small vessels, including glomerular capillaries. Crescentic glomerulonephritis can occur in some cases of HSP.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alport syndrome does not cause crescentic glomerulone­phritis.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ p922)

Granuloma of parenchyma of kidney

questions.text: The pathological feature in Wegener’s granulomatosis on renal biopsy is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Focal necrotizing glomerulonephritis

Option B:

Focal necrotizing glomerulonephritis is a hallmark of GPA. This reflects active glomerular inflammation and necrosis without significant immune deposits, characteristic of pauci-immune glomerulonephritis.

  • ‘The renal lesions range from a mild/ early disease, where glomeruli show acute focal necrosis with thrombosis of isolated glomerular capillary loops (focal and segmental necrotizing glomerulonephritis) whereas advanced glomerular lesions are characterized by diffuse necrosis and parietal cell proliferation to form crescents (crescentic glomerulonephritis)’……Robbins 
  • Direct quote from Harrison…….. “Necrotizing vas­culitis of small arteries and veins with granuloma for­mation is seen in pulmonary tissue whereas granu­loma formation is rarely seen on renal biopsy”.

Explanation:

Option A: Nodular glomerulosclerosis is not a typical feature of GPA. This finding is more commonly associated with diabetic nephropathy.

Option C: While granulomas are a defining feature of GPA, they are more commonly seen in pulmonary tissue and not as frequently observed within the vascular walls in the kidney on biopsy.

Option D: Similar to option C, granulomas can be found in GPA but are more commonly identified in the respiratory tract than in the parenchyma of the kidney.

Educational Objective:

Wegener’s granulomatosis, or Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis, typically presents on renal biopsy with focal necrotizing glomerulonephritis, often with crescent formation, reflecting its classification as a form of pauci-immune glomerulonephritis. Granulomas, while a central feature in the lungs, are rarely seen in renal biopsies for this condition.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 910)

questions.text: Pathological changes of diabetic nephropathy are all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Focal glomerular sclerosis

 

Option D:

 

Diabetic nephropathy is characterized by several pathological changes, and the options provided are associated with these changes:

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Fibrin caps and capsular drops: These are characteristic of diabetic nephropathy. Fibrin caps are formed from the extravasation of plasma proteins into Bowman's space, and capsular drops are hyaline droplets in the renal tubules.

 

Option B. Kimmelstein-Wilson lesion: This refers to nodular glomerulosclerosis, which is a classic finding in diabetic nephropathy.

 

Option C. Basement membrane thickening: Thickening of the glomerular basement membrane is a hallmark of diabetic nephropathy.

 

Focal glomerular sclerosis (FSGS) is not a typical finding in diabetic nephropathy. It is a separate entity that can be associated with other conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The characteristic pathological features of diabetic nephropathy, include Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesions (nodular glomerulosclerosis), thickening of the glomerular basement membrane, and the presence of fibrin caps and capsular drops.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 923)

questions.text: What is the cause of hypercoagulation in nephrotic syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Loss of antithrombin III (AT III)

 

Option A:

 

Loss of antithrombin III (AT III): In nephrotic syndrome, there is increased urinary loss of proteins including antithrombin III, which is a natural anticoagulant. AT III inhibits thrombin and factor Xa in the coagulation cascade. Its loss contributes significantly to the hypercoagulable state in nephrotic syndrome.

 

Thrombotic and thromboembolic complications are com­mon in nephrotic syndrome due to loss of anticoagulant factor (e.g. antithrombin III, protein C and S) combined with increased platelet activation. Renal vein thrombo­sis is most often a consequence of this hypercoagulative state. There is also increased synthesis of fibrinogen in the liver.

 

The hypercoagulable state in nephrotic syndrome is multifactorial.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Decreased fibrinogen: This statement is incorrect with respect to nephrotic syndrome. Actually, there is an increased synthesis of fibrinogen in the liver, not decreased. Fibrinogen is an acute phase reactant, and its levels are increased in nephrotic syndrome, which contributes to a hypercoagulable state.

 

Option C: Decreased metabolism of vitamin K: This statement is not directly related to the hypercoagulable state in nephrotic syndrome. Vitamin K is essential for the synthesis of certain clotting factors (II, VII, IX, X), and its metabolism can be affected in liver disease, not typically in nephrotic syndrome.

 

Option D: Increase in Protein C: This is not correct. While Protein C is an anticoagulant, similar to antithrombin III, in nephrotic syndrome, there can be a loss of Protein C through the urine, which would contribute to a hypercoagulable state rather than mitigating it.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nephrotic syndrome is associated with a hypercoagulable state primarily due to urinary losses of anticoagulant proteins such as antithrombin III, often leading to thrombotic complications like renal vein thrombosis. The liver's increased synthesis of procoagulant factors such as fibrinogen also contributes to this state.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10h/ 911)

questions.text: Finnish type of nephrotic syndrome is associated with:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nephrin

 

Option A:

 

Nephrin: Nephrin is a key structural and signaling protein that is part of the slit diaphragm of glomerular podocytes in the kidney. Mutations in the gene encoding nephrin (NPHS1) are responsible for Finnish-type congenital nephrotic syndrome. This condition is characterized by massive proteinuria starting in utero or shortly after birth and often leads to renal failure.

 

Lipoid nephrosis or nephrotic syndrome is also called as minimal change disease. Congenital nephrotic syndrome occurs as a result of mutation in the nephrin gene. (Finnish type of nephrotic syndrome)

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Podocin: Podocin is another protein that is important in the structure of the slit diaphragm of podocytes. Mutations in the gene encoding podocin (NPHS2) cause autosomal recessive steroid-resistant nephrotic syndrome, which is different from the Finnish type but also results in significant proteinuria.

 

Option C: Alpha-actinin: Alpha-actinin is a cytoskeletal actin-binding protein that is involved in maintaining the structure of the podocyte foot processes and the slit diaphragm. Mutations here can also cause nephrotic syndrome, but they are not associated with the Finnish type of nephrotic syndrome.

 

Option D: CD2-associated protein (CD2AP): CD2AP is a molecule involved in the structure and function of the slit diaphragm and the actin cytoskeleton in podocytes. Mutations in CD2AP can lead to nephrotic syndrome, highlighting its role in maintaining the glomerular filtration barrier.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Finnish type nephrotic syndrome is caused by mutations in the nephrin gene.

 

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 915)

questions.text: Pauci-immune crescentic glomerulonephritis is associated with:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Granulomatosis with polyangiitis

 

Option A:

 

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA): GPA is closely associated with pauci-immune crescentic glomerulonephritis, which is a type of inflammation of the kidney that does not involve significant deposits of immune complexes or antibodies. ANCA, particularly c-ANCA with PR3 specificity, is commonly found in patients with GPA.

 

Pauci-immune crescentic glomerulonephritis is most commonly associated with ANCA (antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody)-associated vasculitides. Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis, is one of the ANCA-associated vasculitides and is strongly associated with pauci-immune crescentic glomerulonephritis.

 

Explanation:

 

The association of pauci-immune crescentic glomerulonephritis:

 

Option B: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE): SLE can affect the kidneys, leading to lupus nephritis, which often involves the deposition of immune complexes. Therefore, it is not typically classified as pauci-immune.

 

Option C: Henoch-Schonlein purpura (HSP): HSP is characterized by the deposition of IgA immune complexes, particularly affecting the small vessels, and it can lead to a type of crescentic glomerulonephritis but it is not pauci-immune.

 

Option D: Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN): PAN is a systemic necrotizing vasculitis that can affect medium-sized arteries and may cause renal damage. However, it is not primarily associated with pauci-immune crescentic glomerulonephritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pauci-immune crescentic glomerulonephritis is a form of rapidly progressing glomerulonephritis strongly associated with ANCA-associated vasculitides, particularly granulomatosis with polyangiitis. It is characterized by minimal or no immune complex deposition and can be differentiated from other forms of crescentic glomerulonephritis by the lack of significant immune deposits.

 

  • Type I RPGN = anti-GBM disease (Goodpasture’s). 
  • Type II RPGN = immune complex-mediated (SLE, IgA nephropathy, post-infectious)
  • Type III RPGN = pauci-immune (ANCA-associated vasculitis)

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 910)

questions.text: All are non-proliferative glomerulonephritis, except:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mesangiocapillary glomerulonephritis  

 

Option B:

 

Mesangiocapillary glomerulonephritis: This condition, also known as type I membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, is indeed a proliferative type. It's characterized by hypercellularity involving both mesangial cells and capillary loops, along with changes in the basement membrane and mesangial matrix.

 

Glomerular lesions with increased cells in the tufts are often known as proliferative glomerulonephritis. The following are the conditions with proliferative glomerulonephritis

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Membranous glomerulonephritis: This is a type of non-proliferative glomerulonephritis characterized by the thickening of the glomerular basement membrane without an increase in the number of cells (non-proliferative). It is often associated with the presence of immune complexes along the basement membrane.

 

Option C: Diabetic glomerulosclerosis: This refers to changes in the kidneys associated with diabetes mellitus and is characterized by thickening of the basement membrane and mesangial expansion. It does not involve an increase in the number of glomerular cells and is therefore considered non-proliferative.

 

Option D: Amyloidosis: Amyloidosis in the kidney leads to the deposition of amyloid proteins in the glomerulus. It is also non-proliferative, as it does not involve an increase in glomerular cell number.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Proliferative glomerulonephritis is defined by an increase in cellular elements within the glomerular structure, which is evident in mesangiocapillary glomerulonephritis

  • Non-proliferative: membranous glomerulonephritis, diabetic glomerulosclerosis, and amyloidosis.

 

(Ref: Anderson 10th /917)

questions.text: Kidney biopsy from a child with hemolytic uremic syndrome characteristically most likely presents features of:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thrombotic microangiopathy

 

Option A:

 

Thrombotic Microangiopathy: This is the correct diagnosis for hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS). It involves the presence of microthrombi in the small blood vessels of the kidney, which leads to mechanical damage to red blood cells as they pass through the partially occluded vessels, causing a characteristic type of anemia known as microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, along with thrombocytopenia due to platelet consumption and acute kidney injury.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Proliferative Glomerulonephritis: This involves an increase in the number of cells in the glomeruli, typically due to an immune or inflammatory response. It is not typically associated with HUS, which is characterized by microangiopathic changes rather than cellular proliferation in the glomeruli.

 

Option C: Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS): This condition is characterized by segments of the glomeruli showing scarring, which can lead to proteinuria and nephrotic syndrome. While FSGS can result in renal failure, it is not a characteristic feature of HUS.

 

Option D: Minimal Change Disease: This is a kidney disorder that causes nephrotic syndrome, especially in children, and is characterized by minimal changes detectable by light microscopy. It's associated with good prognosis and typically responds well to steroids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients presenting with the clinical triad of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury, a kidney biopsy is likely to reveal thrombotic microangiopathy, a pathology characteristic of hemolytic uremic syndrome.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 939)

questions.text: Serum C3 is persistently low in the following except:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Post streptococcal glomerulonephritis

 

Option A:

 

Post Streptococcal Glomerulonephritis: After an infection with certain strains of Streptococcus, serum C3 levels typically decrease due to activation of the complement system. However, this decrease is transient and serum C3 levels usually normalize within 6 to 8 weeks. Therefore, persistently low serum C3 levels are not characteristic of poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis.

 

Explanation:

 

The terms of serum C3 levels in different renal pathologies:

 

Option B: Membranoproliferative Glomerulonephritis type II: This condition can cause persistently low serum C3 levels, often related to the presence of C3 nephritic factors that continuously activate the alternative complement pathway, leading to complement consumption.

 

Option C: Lupus Nephritis: In systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), including lupus nephritis, both classical and alternative complement pathways can be activated by immune complexes, leading to persistent depression of complement components, including C3.

 

Option D: Glomerulonephritis Related to Bacterial Endocarditis: This condition is also associated with immune complex deposition that can consume complement. Persistent low serum C3 levels may be observed, depending on the chronicity and activity of the infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serum complement levels, specifically C3, can be a valuable clinical marker in the diagnosis and monitoring of glomerular diseases. Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis typically presents with transient low serum C3 levels, which recover within a few weeks, unlike other conditions such as membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, lupus nephritis, and glomerulonephritis related to bacterial endocarditis, which may show persistent low levels indicative of ongoing complement activation and consumption.

 

C3 Levels in Different Types of GN:

 

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th 906)

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the clinic with recurrent episodes of gross hematuria following upper respiratory tract infections. Which of the following is not true about Berger’s disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Absence of associated proteinuria is pathogno­mic

Option D: The absence of proteinuria is not pathognomonic for Berger’s disease; on the contrary, proteinuria can be present and varies in severity.

Berger's disease, also known as IgA nephropathy, is characterized by the deposition of IgA immune complexes in the glomerular mesangium. While it is true that Berger's disease often presents with hematuria (either gross or microscopic), the absence of associated proteinuria is not pathognomonic. In fact, proteinuria can occur in some cases of IgA nephropathy, and the severity can vary. Proteinuria is not consistently absent in Berger's disease.

Explanation:

Option A: Berger’s disease, or IgA nephropathy, indeed shows mesangial proliferation. This is often a focal and segmental process within the glomeruli and is characteristic of the disease.

Option B: Hematuria, which may be gross (visible) or microscopic, is a common finding in Berger's disease and can be one of the initial signs of the condition.

Option C: Immunofluorescence typically shows mesangial deposits primarily composed of IgA, and sometimes IgG and C3 may be present. The predominance of IgA deposition is a defining feature of IgA nephropathy.

Educational Objective:

The characteristic pathological feature of Berger’s disease is the deposition of IgA immune complexes in the glomerular mesangium. IgA nephropathy can present with a range of symptoms from isolated hematuria to nephrotic syndrome with significant proteinuria. A lack of proteinuria is not diagnostic of the disease.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th /920)

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with a 3-month history of recurrent sinusitis, cough, and hemoptysis. Physical examination reveals saddle-nose deformity and purpuric skin lesions on the lower extremities. Laboratory studies show elevated inflammatory markers and positive anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (c-ANCA). In Wegener’s granulomatosis, kidney has which of the following lesions?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Crescentic glomerulonephritis

 

Option C:

 

Wegener's granulomatosis often presents with necrotizing granulomatous inflammation in the respiratory tract and necrotizing vasculitis affecting small- to medium-sized vessels. In the kidney, this vasculitis can lead to crescentic glomerulonephritis, which is a characteristic renal manifestation.

 

Explanation:

 

Options A: and Option C: glomerular and interstitial granuloma is not a typical finding in Wegener's granulomatosis.

 

Wegener's granulomatosis primarily involves small vessels and may cause granulomatous inflammation in the interstitial tissues, but glomerular and interstitial granulomas are not a defining feature.

 

Option D: Glomerulosclerosis is not a typical lesion seen in Wegener's granulomatosis. The primary renal involvement is characterized by crescentic glomerulonephritis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In Wegener’s granulomatosis kidney shows crescentic glomerulonephritis.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/909)

questions.text: The electron microscopy is virtually diagnostic in renal biopsy study of:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Alport syndrome

 

Option C:

 

Alport syndrome shows a characteristic electron microscopy finding of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM), which is described as basket-weaving, due to splitting and lamellation of the lamina densa. This is a pathognomonic feature.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Goodpasture syndrome is characterized by the presence of anti-GBM antibodies leading to glomerulonephritis and pulmonary hemorrhage. Electron microscopy may show non-specific findings of glomerular damage rather than the specific changes seen in Alport syndrome.

 

Option B: Churg-Strauss syndrome, also known as eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis, is a form of vasculitis. Renal involvement can occur, but electron microscopy findings are not diagnostic of the condition.

 

Option D: Wegener’s granulomatosis, now known as granulomatosis with polyangiitis, may show evidence of small vessel vasculitis on biopsy, but electron microscopy is not typically diagnostic for this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alport syndrome's definitive morphological lesions are observable only by electron microscopy, which reveals a distinctive appearance of the GBM.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 922)

choices.text: Focal and segmental glomerulosclerosis

questions.text: Mesangial deposits of monoclonal kappa/lambda light chains in indicative of?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Amyloidosis

Option D:

Amyloidosis is the correct answer, as it is specifically associated with the deposition of abnormal proteins, including AL proteins made of immunoglobulin light chains, within the kidney and other organs.

Mesangial deposits of monoclonal kappa/lambda light chains suggest the diagnosis of Amyloidosis. In primary Amyloidosis AL protein is deposited in the organs, which is made of light chains (usually lambda type) of immunoglobulins. Renal amyloi­dosis is the most common cause of death due to amyloidosis (including both primary and second­ary amyloidosis).

Explanation:

Option A: Mesangioproliferative glomerulonephritis involves proliferation of mesangial cells within the kidney but is not specifically associated with the deposition of light chains.

Option B: Focal and segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is characterized by segments of scarring in some glomeruli but does not feature light chain deposits.

Option C: Kimmelstiel-Wilson lesions are specific to diabetic nephropathy and exhibit nodular glomerulosclerosis, which also does not involve monoclonal light chains.

Educational Objective:

Renal amyloidosis can present with mesangial deposits of monoclonal kappa or lambda light chains and is associated with primary amyloidosis.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 934)

questions.text: In renal disease, albumin is first to appear in urine because?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Has molecular weight slightly greater than the molecules normally getting filtered

Option B:

The molecular weight of albumin is slightly greater than that of molecules normally filtered; however, albumin is still small enough (around 7nm in diameter) to be filtered if the charge barrier is compromised.

The filtration of any substance through glomerular filtration layer depends on two factors as described below:

 

In some renal diseases, the anionic charge of the fil­tration membrane is lost and this allows negatively charged particles of diameter 8 nm to pass through it resulting in proteinuria. Albumin has a diameter of 7 nm and it starts appearing in urine as soon as the negative charge of filtration layer disappears.

Explanation:

Option A: High concentration in plasma does not inherently cause albumin to be filtered into the urine; it is the selectivity of the glomerular filter that is important.

Option C: The albumin-globulin ratio in the blood does not affect the selectivity of the glomerular filtration barrier directly.

Option D: Tubular reabsorption and sensitivity to albumin do not primarily determine its filtration, although damage to tubular cells can contribute to proteinuria if they are unable to reabsorb filtered proteins.

Educational Objective:

The main reason albumin is the first to appear in urine during renal disease is due to its size and charge. Normally, albumin is repelled by the negatively charged glomerular basement membrane, but when the charge barrier is lost due to renal disease, albumin can pass through more easily.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 911)

choices.text: Fusion of foot processes of the glomerular epithelial cells
Deposition of electron dense material in the basement membrane

questions.text: A 7 year old boy presented with generalized edema. Urine examination revealed marked albuminuria. Serum biochemical examinations showed hypoalbuminemia with hyperlipidemia. Kidney biopsy was undertaken. On light microscopic examination, the kidney appeared normal. Electron microscopic examination is most likely to reveal:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fusion of foot process of the glomerular epi­thelial cells

 

Option A:

 

Fusion of foot processes of the glomerular epithelial cells is characteristic of minimal change disease. Electron microscopy will reveal effacement or fusion of the podocyte foot processes without immune complex deposition or complement activation.

 

The child is presenting with features likely of Nephrotic syndrome whose most frequent cause in children is minimal change disease or lipoid nephrosis.

 

  • Light microscopy there is no abnormality whereas on electron microscopy there is fusion of foot pro­cesses of the glomerular epithelial cells with normal glomeruli.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Rarefaction of the glomerular basement membrane is not a feature of MCD but may be seen in other kidney diseases, such as Alport syndrome.

 

Option C: Deposition of electron-dense material in the basement membrane is typically observed in diseases such as membranous nephropathy, not MCD.

 

Option D: A thin basement membrane is characteristic of thin basement membrane disease, a condition separate from MCD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary finding in minimal change disease on electron microscopy is the effacement or fusion of podocyte foot processes, which helps in distinguishing it from other glomerular diseases that may present with normal findings on light microscopy but show specific abnormalities on electron microscopy.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 914)

questions.text: The prognosis of rapidly proliferating glomerulonephritis depends upon which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Number of crescents

 

Option A:

 

The Number of Crescents: This is the most important prognostic factor in rapidly proliferating glomerulonephritis. The more glomeruli that contain crescents, especially when more than 50% of the glomeruli are involved, the worse the prognosis is likely to be due to the associated reduction in functional renal tissue.

 

Crescents are formed by the proliferation of cells in Bowman's space (glomerular parietal epithelial cells, infiltrating monocytes/macrophages, and other cells). The presence of crescents indicates severe glomerular injury and inflammation, and the degree of crescent formation correlates with the extent of damage. The more crescents present, the greater the loss of functional glomerular tissue, leading to impaired kidney function and poorer prognosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Size of Crescents: While the size of crescents might reflect the severity of the initial injury, it is not as directly correlated with the prognosis as the number of affected glomeruli.

 

Option C: Shape of Crescents: The shape does not typically provide prognostic information. Crescents, by definition, are semi-lunar and their presence, regardless of shape, suggests significant pathology.

 

Option D: Cellularity of Crescents: Cellularity can give clues about the activity of the disease process (more cellular crescents may indicate more active disease), but again, the number of crescents is a stronger prognostic indicator.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In rapidly proliferating glomerulonephritis, the prognosis is primarily dependent on the number of crescents within the glomeruli, as this reflects the degree of glomerular damage and potential loss of kidney function.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 909)

choices.text: Tubular cell + mesangial cell + fibrin

questions.text: Crescents are derived from which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Epithelial cells + fibrin + macrophage

 

Option A:

 

Epithelial cells + fibrin + macrophage Crescents are formed within Bowman's space during severe glomerular injury. Parietal epithelial cells line Bowman's capsule, and they proliferate in response to injury. Macrophages infiltrate the space as part of the inflammatory response, and fibrin is deposited due to the leakage of plasma proteins through the injured glomerular capillaries. This option correctly identifies the components of a crescent in proliferative forms of glomerulonephritis.

 

Explanation:

 

The composition of crescents in glomerulonephritis:

 

Option B: Mesangial cell + fibrin + macrophage.  While mesangial cells are indeed a component of the glomerulus and can proliferate in response to injury, they are not typically a part of the cellular makeup of crescents. Crescents are primarily composed of parietal epithelial cells, not mesangial cells.

 

Option C: Tubular cell + mesangial cell + fibrin Tubular cells are part of the nephron but not of the glomerulus, and they do not contribute to crescent formation. Mesangial cells, as mentioned earlier, reside within the glomerulus but do not form crescents.

 

Option D: Neutrophil + tubular cell + fibrin Neutrophils may be present in the glomerulus as part of an inflammatory response but are not a defining component of crescents. Tubular cells are not involved in crescent formation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Crescents are formed by proliferation of parietal cells and by migration of monocytes and macrophages into the urinary space. Neutrophils and lymphocytes may be present. Fibrin strands are frequently promi­nent between the cellular layers in the crescents. The escape of fibrinogen into Bowman space and its conver­sion to fibrin are an important contributor to crescent formation.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 911)

questions.text: Flea bitten appearance of the kidney is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Malignant hypertension

 

Option A:

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Benign hypertension, also known as essential hypertension, is associated with long-standing high blood pressure. It can lead to hypertensive nephrosclerosis, characterized by arteriolar hyalinosis and ischemic changes in the kidney. However, "flea-bitten" appearance is not a specific term associated with this condition.

 

Option C: Chronic pyelonephritis is a condition characterized by chronic inflammation of the renal parenchyma, often secondary to recurrent urinary tract infections. It typically presents with scarring and atrophy of the renal papillae.

 

Option D: Long standing and uncontrolled diabetes can lead to diabetic nephropathy. This condition is characterized by glomerular basement membrane thickening and nodular glomerulosclerosis (Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mnemonic for differential diagnosis of flea bitten kid­ney: We HaTe PSM

 

  • We -Wegener’s granulomatosis

  • HaTe – Henoch Schonlein purpura; HUS;TTP

  • P- Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN); Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN)

  • S-Subacute bacterial endocarditis (SABE)

  • M- Malignant hypertension.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 939)

choices.text: Heavy proteinuria, high cholesterol, high ASO titre
Heavy proteinuria, hematuria, low ASO titre
Mild proteinuria, hematuria, high ASO titre
Mild proteinuria, high cholesterol, normal ASO titre

questions.text: Post streptococcal glomerulonephritis in children is diagnosed by:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mild proteinuria, hematuria, high ASO titre

Option C:

Explanation:

  • Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) typically occurs after a streptococcal infection (such as strep throat or impetigo).
  • Clinical features of PSGN include mild proteinuria, hematuria, and elevated antistreptolysin O (ASO) titers.
  • Heavy proteinuria is more characteristic of nephrotic syndrome, which is not the typical presentation of PSGN.
  • Elevated cholesterol levels are more associated with nephrotic syndrome rather than PSGN.

Educational objective:

Clinical features of Post streptococcal glomerulonephritis in children include mild proteinuria, hematuria, and elevated antistreptolysin O (ASO) titers.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 906)

choices.text: Renal biopsy having thin basement membrane

questions.text: IgA nephropathy is characterized by all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Renal biopsy having thin basement membrane

 

Option D:

 

A thin basement membrane is not characteristic of IgA nephropathy; this finding is more commonly associated with thin basement membrane disease, which is a different condition. IgA nephropathy is characterized by mesangial cell proliferation and mesangial deposits of IgA immune complexes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Hypertension can occur in IgA nephropathy due to ongoing kidney damage and is a common symptom associated with many chronic kidney diseases.

 

Option B: Hematuria, or blood in the urine, is a hallmark of IgA nephropathy. It can be recurrent and is often noticed following an upper respiratory tract infection, due to the mesangial deposition of IgA immune complexes.

 

Option C: IgA nephropathy can present with features of nephritic syndrome, which includes hematuria, variable degrees of proteinuria, and sometimes reduced kidney function. It does not typically present as full-blown nephrotic syndrome, which is characterized by severe proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, edema, and hyperlipidemia.

 

Educational objective:

 

IgA nephropathy, or Berger's disease, is identified by the presence of IgA deposits within the glomerular mesangium, which can lead to symptoms such as hematuria and hypertension. A thin basement membrane is not a feature of this condition and is typically observed in a separate condition known as thin basement membrane disease.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 922)

questions.text: Microalbuminuria is defined as protein levels of:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 30-300 mg/d

Option C:

Explanation:

Microalbuminuria refers to the excretion of a moderately increased amount of albumin in the urine. The normal urinary albumin excretion rate is less than 30 mg/day.

  • Microalbuminuria is often defined as a urinary albumin excretion rate of 30-300 mg/day. It is an early sign of kidney damage and is commonly associated with conditions such as diabetes and hypertension.

Educational objective:

Microalbuminuria is defined as protein levels of 30-300 mg/day.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 923)

choices.text: Persistent hepatitis C infections

questions.text: Type I membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis is commonly associated with all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Partial lipodystrophy

Option C:

Partial lipodystrophy is associated with C3 nephritic factor (C3NeF). It is a rare disorder characterized by selective loss of adipose tissue. It has been reported as an association with Type II MPGN and not type I MPGN.

Explanation:

Option A: Type I membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN) can be associated with SLE as it is associated with immune complex-mediated glomerulonephritis.

Option B: Type I MPGN has a strong association with chronic infections, particularly persistent hepatitis C infections. The immune complexes formed during chronic infections can deposit in the glomeruli, leading to MPGN.

Option D: Type I MPGN has been associated with various neoplastic diseases, including hematological malignancies. The presence of malignancies can contribute to the formation of immune complexes, leading to glomerular deposition.

Educational objective:

Type I MPGN is linked with conditions like systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), chronic infections such as persistent hepatitis C, and certain neoplastic diseases due to the formation of immune complexes and their deposition in the kidneys. In contrast, partial lipodystrophy, a disorder characterized by the loss of adipose tissue, is commonly associated with Type II MPGN due to the presence of C3 nephritic factor (C3NeF), which stabilizes the alternative pathway C3 convertase leading to persistent activation of the complement system.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 918)

questions.text: In which of the following conditions bilateral contracted kidneys are characteristically seen?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Benign Nephrosclerosis

 

Option D:

 

Benign nephrosclerosis is associated with long-standing hypertension and is characterized by symmetrically contracted kidneys. This is a result of chronic, benign vascular changes in the kidneys due to hypertension.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Amyloidosis is a condition characterized by the deposition of abnormal proteins (amyloid) in various organs, including the kidneys. It can lead to enlarged, pale kidneys rather than contracted ones.

 

Option B: Chronic diabetes can lead to diabetic nephropathy, which is associated with diffuse glomerulosclerosis. In the early stages, kidneys may be enlarged, but they typically do not show bilateral contraction.

 

Option C: Polycystic kidney disease: Characterised by enlarged kidney

 

Educational objective:

 

Direct quote from Robbins……‘In benign nephrosclerosis, kidneys are either normal or moderately reduced in size on gross appearance. The loss of mass is due mainly to cortical scarring and shrinking’.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 935)

questions.text: Persistent low C3 complement level is not found in:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis

Option A:

Poststreptococcal Glomerulonephritis - Although associated with transient hypocomplementemia, poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis does not typically present with persistent low levels of C3. C3 levels generally return to normal within several weeks after onset.

Explanation:

Option B: Mesangiocapillary Glomerulonephritis - Persistent low C3 levels are commonly found in this condition due to continuous activation of the complement pathway, making it an important diagnostic marker.

Option C: Cryoglobulinemia - This condition involves the formation of immune complexes that can consume complement proteins, leading to persistently low levels of C3.

Option D: SLE - Systemic lupus erythematosus, an autoimmune disease, often involves the formation of immune complexes and is typically associated with a persistent decrease in complement proteins, including C3.

Educational Objective:

Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis typically exhibits a transient drop in C3 levels that resolves with the acute phase, while conditions like mesangiocapillary glomerulonephritis, cryoglobulinemia, and SLE can show sustained low levels indicative of ongoing immune complex activity and complement activation.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 906)

questions.text: Urine analysis of a patient with haematuria and hypercalciuria is most likely to reveal which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Isomorphic RBC

Option A:

Isomorphic RBCs in the urine refer to the presence of intact red blood cells without any significant changes in shape or size. The presence of isomorphic RBCs in urine suggests bleeding from a non glomerular cause in the kidney or the lower urinary tract, such as the bladder or urethra.

Explanation:

Option B: The presence of RBC casts in urine indicates glomerular bleeding. Glomerular bleeding can occur in conditions such as glomerulonephritis or vasculitis. The formation of casts occurs within the renal tubules and is a characteristic finding in glomerular diseases.

Option C: Nephrotic range proteinuria refers to the excessive loss of protein in the urine, typically exceeding 3.5 grams per day. This condition is often associated with glomerular diseases, such as membranous nephropathy or minimal change disease. It may present with features like edema, hypoalbuminemia, and hyperlipidemia.

Option D: Eosinophiluria refers to the presence of eosinophils in the urine. It can be associated with allergic reactions, interstitial nephritis, or certain parasitic infections.

Educational Objective:

To diagnose the cause of hematuria in patients presenting with haematuria and hypercalciuria, it is crucial to examine the morphology of red blood cells (RBCs) in the urine.The presence of isomorphic RBCs implies bleeding from areas like the renal calyces, pelvis, ureter, bladder, or urethra, where the RBCs do not undergo significant alterations in shape.

 

(Ref: Paediatric Nephrology 5th /141, 190 by Dr R.N. Srivas­tava and Dr Arvind Bagga)

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with a history of intravenous drug abuse presents with worsening kidney function. Renal biopsy reveals collapsing variant of focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS). Which of the following features is characteristic of this variant and is associated with a worse prognosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Collapsing

 

Option B:

 

The collapsing variant is characterized by the collapse of glomerular capillaries and overt tuft collapse, which leads to rapid progression of renal disease and a poorer prognosis, making this the correct answer.

 

Five mutually exclusive variants of focal seg­mental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) may be dis­tinguished by the pathological findings seen on renal biopsy

 

  • Collapsing variant

  • Glomerular tip lesion variant

  • Cellular variant

  • Perihilar variant

  • Not otherwise specified variant (NOS)

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: The tip variant of FSGS affects the segment of the glomerulus near the proximal tubule and is associated with better outcomes compared to other variants.

 

Option C: NOS (not otherwise specified) variant is the most common type of FSGS and has a variable prognosis that is generally not as poor as the collapsing variant.

 

Option D: The perihilar variant of FSGS has sclerotic lesions predominantly at the vascular pole of the glomerulus and does not typically progress as rapidly as the collapsing variant.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The NOS variant is the most common subtype and collapsing FSGS has worst prognosis.

 

(Ref: Robbin’s 10th/ 916)

choices.text: Focal and segmental glomerulosclerosis
Rapidly non progressive glomerulonephritis

questions.text: Crescent formation is characteristic of which of the following glomerular disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis

Option B:

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis is indeed associated with crescent formation, which can be seen in most of the glomeruli. This type of glomerulonephritis progresses quickly, often leading to renal failure in a short period of time.

  • Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, also known as crescentic glomerulonephritis is charac­terized by the presence of crescents in most of the glomeruli.
  • Crescents are produced by proliferation of the pari­etal epithelial cells of Bowman’s capsule and by infiltration of monocytes and macrophages.

Explanation:

Option A: Minimal change disease typically presents with nephrotic syndrome and is characterized by minimal changes on light microscopy; specifically, it lacks inflammatory changes or crescents.

Option C: Focal and segmental glomerulosclerosis involves scarring in specific areas of the glomeruli. It is not primarily associated with crescent formation.

Option D: The term 'rapidly non-progressive glomerulonephritis' is not commonly used. However, any non-progressive form of glomerulonephritis would not typically feature crescent formation, which is indicative of a more aggressive disease process.

Educational Objective:

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis is characterized by the formation of crescents, which are structures formed by the proliferation of parietal epithelial cells of Bowman’s capsule and infiltration of monocytes and macrophages. This condition requires prompt diagnosis and treatment due to its rapid progression and potential to quickly lead to irreversible renal damage.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 909)

choices.text: Hypertrophy and necrosis of visceral epithelium

questions.text: Which of the following is a feature of collapsing glomerulopathy?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Hypertrophy and necrosis of visceral epithe­lium

Option D:

Collapsing glomerulopathy is a distinct pattern of glomerular injury characterized by hypertrophy and necrosis of visceral epithelial cells (podocytes).

Explanation:

Option A: Tuft necrosis refers to the destruction of the glomerular tuft, and this is not a characteristic feature of collapsing glomerulopathy.

Option B: Mesangiolysis involves disruption of mesangial cells and matrix, but it is not a prominent feature of collapsing glomerulopathy.

Option C: Parietal epithelial proliferation is not a typical finding in collapsing glomerulopathy; instead, the pathology primarily involves changes in the visceral epithelial cells.

Educational objective:

Hypertrophy and necrosis of visceral epithelium is a distinctive feature of collapsing glomerulopathy.

 

(Ref. Robbin’s 10th/ 917)

choices.text: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis
Minimal change disease

questions.text: Most common cause of nephritic syndrome in adults is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Berger disease

Option A:

IgA nephropathy, also known as Berger's disease, is a common cause of nephritic syndrome in adults. It is characterized by the deposition of IgA immune complexes in the glomeruli, leading to inflammation and damage. This condition often presents with recurrent episodes of gross hematuria, usually following upper respiratory tract infections.

Explanation:

Option B: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis is more commonly associated with nephrotic syndrome than nephritic syndrome. It involves scarring of some glomeruli, leading to proteinuria.

Option C: Membranous glomerulonephritis is also more commonly associated with nephrotic syndrome. It involves thickening of the glomerular basement membrane and can present with proteinuria.

Option D: Minimal change disease is a common cause of nephrotic syndrome in children. It is characterized by minimal changes on light microscopy but significant proteinuria.

Educational objective:

Most common cause of nephritic syndrome in adults is Berger’s disease.

 

(Ref: Robbins 10th/ 920)
